name: Mount Everest
lead: The highest mountain in the world, Everest has long symbolized human endurance and exploration.
content: Mount Everest, known locally as Sagarmatha in Nepal and Chomolungma in Tibet, stands at 8,848 metres as the tallest peak on Earth.
The first confirmed ascent in 1953 by Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay made global history and inspired generations of climbers.
Today, Everest attracts climbers from all over the world, but it also raises concerns about overcrowding and environmental impact.
Despite the risks, Everest remains one of the greatest challenges and achievements in human exploration.

name: K2
lead: Often called the 'Savage Mountain,' K2 is considered more dangerous to climb than Everest.
content: K2, the second-highest mountain in the world, rises to 8,611 metres in the Karakoram range.
It is infamous for its extreme difficulty and high fatality rate among climbers.
Unlike Everest, K2 has no easy routes, and weather conditions are notoriously unpredictable.
Its striking pyramid shape dominates the Karakoram skyline and commands respect from all who see it.

name: Kangchenjunga
lead: Once thought to be the highest peak, Kangchenjunga is revered as sacred in local traditions.
content: Kangchenjunga is the third-highest mountain on Earth at 8,586 metres.
It lies on the border of Nepal and India, where it holds spiritual significance.
Climbers often stop short of the true summit out of respect for local beliefs.
The name means 'Five Treasures of Snow,' symbolizing gold, silver, gems, grain, and holy scriptures.

name: Lhotse
lead: Lhotse, Everest’s neighbor, is the fourth-highest mountain and shares much of its route.
content: Lhotse stands at 8,516 metres and is closely connected to Mount Everest.
Its climbing route diverges from Everest near the South Col.
Though overshadowed by Everest, it presents its own formidable challenges.
Lhotse’s steep icy faces are considered some of the most difficult terrain in the Himalayas.

name: Makalu
lead: Known for its pyramid-like shape, Makalu is one of the most striking 8,000-metre peaks.
content: Makalu reaches 8,485 metres and is located southeast of Everest.
Its sharp ridges and steep pitches make it a technically demanding climb.
The peak is famous for its dramatic silhouette when viewed from a distance.
Makalu was first successfully climbed in 1955 by a French expedition.

name: Cho Oyu
lead: Cho Oyu, the 'Turquoise Goddess,' is considered one of the easier 8,000-metre peaks.
content: Cho Oyu stands at 8,188 metres and sits on the Nepal–Tibet border.
It is often considered the best peak for those attempting their first 8,000-metre climb.
Its name means 'Turquoise Goddess' in Tibetan, reflecting local cultural reverence.
The mountain provides stunning views of Everest and the surrounding Himalayas.

name: Dhaulagiri
lead: Dhaulagiri, the 'White Mountain,' was once thought to be the world’s highest peak.
content: Dhaulagiri rises to 8,167 metres in Nepal.
Its name means 'White Mountain' in Sanskrit, a reference to its massive snowy slopes.
The mountain is known for its sheer faces and steep ridges.
It presents a dramatic contrast with the nearby Annapurna range.

name: Manaslu
lead: Known as the 'Mountain of the Spirit,' Manaslu is revered by locals and climbers alike.
content: Manaslu stands at 8,163 metres in west-central Nepal.
Its name is derived from the Sanskrit word 'Manasa,' meaning soul or intellect.
The first ascent was achieved by a Japanese team in 1956.
Today, it is a popular peak for climbers seeking a less crowded alternative to Everest.

name: Nanga Parbat
lead: Nicknamed the 'Killer Mountain,' Nanga Parbat is notorious for its deadly climbing history.
content: Nanga Parbat reaches 8,126 metres in Pakistan’s Gilgit-Baltistan region.
Its massive south face, the Rupal Face, is the world’s highest mountain face.
Early expeditions faced tragic losses, giving it a deadly reputation.
Despite its history, it remains a magnet for elite mountaineers.

name: Annapurna I
lead: Annapurna I was the first 8,000-metre peak ever successfully climbed, but it is also one of the deadliest.
content: Annapurna I, at 8,091 metres, was first climbed in 1950 by a French expedition.
It has one of the highest fatality rates among the 8,000-metre peaks.
The Annapurna massif is also home to some of Nepal’s most famous trekking routes.
Its name comes from the goddess Annapurna, associated with nourishment and food.

name: Gasherbrum I
lead: Gasherbrum I, also known as 'Hidden Peak,' is the 11th-highest mountain in the world.
content: Gasherbrum I rises to 8,080 metres in the Karakoram range.
It was first climbed in 1958 by an American team.
The name 'Gasherbrum' means 'beautiful mountain' in Balti language.
Its remote location makes it less frequently climbed than its neighbors.

name: Broad Peak
lead: Named for its wide summit ridge, Broad Peak is a massive presence in the Karakoram.
content: Broad Peak stands at 8,051 metres near K2 in the Karakoram range.
Its summit ridge stretches for over 1.5 kilometres, giving it its descriptive name.
The first ascent was made in 1957 by an Austrian team.
Though not as well-known as K2, it remains a significant challenge for mountaineers.

name: Gasherbrum II
lead: Gasherbrum II is considered one of the more accessible 8,000-metre peaks in the Karakoram.
content: Gasherbrum II reaches 8,035 metres and is the 13th-highest mountain in the world.
It was first climbed in 1956 by an Austrian team.
The mountain is often chosen by climbers attempting their first Karakoram 8,000er.
Its relative accessibility does not diminish the dangers of extreme altitude.

name: Shishapangma
lead: The only 8,000-metre peak located entirely within Tibet, Shishapangma is the lowest of the 14 giants.
content: Shishapangma rises to 8,027 metres in Tibet.
It was the last of the 8,000ers to be climbed, with the first ascent in 1964 by a Chinese team.
Its relative accessibility has made it a popular goal for climbers acclimatizing to high altitudes.
Despite being the 'lowest' of the group, it is still a formidable mountain.
